Representative_Docs: ['Dora (Dori) Missirlian Crawford Birth: 1946 Death: 2025 A devoted and loving wife, mother, sister, grandmother, aunt, sister-in-law, mother-in-law, teacher, and friend to many. Dori touched every life she encountered. She was kind, humble, wise, independent, adventurous, fun, loyal, compassionate, giving, and spiritual‚Ä¶..a beautiful human being in every way. Dori passed away peacefully on November 1, 2025 in the loving company of her family. Dori was born on April 11, 1946 in Aleppo, Syria. Her parents, Haratune and Lydia Missirlian, moved with Dori and her older sister Sonia to Beirut, Lebanon before emigrating to Chicago. Eventually the family, which now included her younger brother John, settled in Fresno, where her father served for 32 years as minister of the Pilgrim Armenian Congregational Church. As a youth, Dori was an active participant in many church activities and loved singing and playing the piano. Dori graduated from Fresno High School in 1963 and Fresno State in 1967. After graduating, she began a career in education, teaching both in California and abroad. Her three years spent teaching in Europe sparked a deep love of travel, adventure, and exploration that stayed with her throughout her life. In', 'Tosca Theresa Pardini Birth: 1931 Death: 2025 Tosca Theresa Pardini, beloved mother, Nonna, great grandmother, and cherished friend, passed away peacefully on Sunday, November 16, surrounded by the love of her family. On a dark, cloudy day, as the Frank Sinatra song ‚ÄúFly Me to the Moon‚Äù played softly, a single ray of sunshine broke through and gently touched her beautiful face as she took her final breath with her family by her side. She was born at home in San Francisco on May 7, 1931, and she carried the spirit of the city with her throughout her life. Tosca later made her home in Ross, California, where she built a life centered on family, tradition, and enduring love. Tosca met the love of her life, Sergio Pardini, and they were married on February 17, 1952, at Saints Peter and Paul Church in North Beach. For sixty one adventure filled years they were inseparable and shared a deep devotion that guided their lives together. Known for her warmth, elegance, and quiet strength, Tosca created a home where everyone felt welcome. She was deeply proud of her Italian heritage and the traditions she lovingly passed down. Her kindness and grace touched all who knew her. Tosca loved traveling the world with Ser', 'Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser Birth: 1950 Death: 2025 Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser March 16, 1950-December 15, 2025 passed away peacefully surrounded by her family at her home in San Pancho, Mexico. Survived by her husband of 41 years, Phil Schlosser, her mother Gerry, daughter Kelly Noel, son Kevin Noel and wife Jennifer and her grandchildren Trevor and Lena. She was preceded in death by her father, Wayne Henry Jordan and brother Michael Wayne Jordan. Linda was born and raised in San Rafael, CA and graduated from Terra Linda High School. Linda loved sunshine, warm weather and travel. She was an outstanding cook and loved to entertain. Her great adventure was moving to Mexico, building a wonderful home filled with warmth, family, friends and great meals. She loved traveling throughout Mexico and Italy. Her family requests that gifts in lieu of flowers be made in Linda‚Äôs name to St. Jude Children‚Äôs Research Hospital. Representative_Docs: ['Asking Eric: Family, friends don‚Äôt seem to appreciate time I put into tedious Christmas cookie tradition Dear Eric: My late mother made a special Christmas cookie that required tedious decorating, considering each person‚Äôs personal preference for toppings, and giving them as gifts to family and friends. They always had a place of honor on our family Christmas table. When she was no longer able, she gave me the cookie cutter, and my daughters and I took over the family tradition. It takes the three of us several days to make, bake, decorate, package and mail cookies to family members around the country. We enjoy doing it and feel like we‚Äôre continuing the fun and festive tradition. However, in recent years, not all of the recipients acknowledge receipt. At some point in their lives, they have all helped Grandma decorate, so they know the time involved. Because of past delivery issues, I track the boxes and inquire if I haven‚Äôt heard from them in a couple of days. Last year, one response was ‚Äúyes we got them.‚Äù This feels unappreciative! In the past most would text a picture of their children with the cookies, which we really enjoyed. We rarely see any of them anymore, as they are busy raising their families and don‚Äôt live nearby. This seems like a way for us to continue somewhat of a co', 'Asking Eric: Can mom work through tension in son‚Äôs relationship with dad so they can celebrate special birthday? We did a special trip for his older brother when he turned 40 and would like to do something special for this son‚Äôs 40th as well. Our daughter-in-law has made special plans for him and we are not included. I understand that, but I need some ideas as to how to celebrate this extra special year without rocking the boat. I love my son with all my heart, as I do all my children, and want his 40th birthday to be memorable in a positive way. Any suggestions? ‚Äì Mom Who Wants to Celebrate Dear Mom: The issues your son and your husband are having may be an obstacle, but they aren‚Äôt insurmountable. And the thing that can get them on the path to resolution is the same thing that can get you answers about how to celebrate your son: open communication. It‚Äôs not within your purview to try to fix things between them, but you have your own relationship with your son and so I‚Äôd encourage you to reach out and tell him what you told me: you want to celebrate him, you know things are difficult, and you‚Äôre lookin', 'Asking Eric: After 6 years sober, man is frustrated by his family‚Äôs hold on their hurt and distrust Dear Eric: I‚Äôve just turned 40 this past year. The last 15 years I was in a horrible drug addiction. I lied and hurt and did terrible things to a lot of people, especially my family. About eight years ago they officially disowned me. Understandable. I‚Äôve cleaned up and got my act together six years ago. At first, I tried to force my way back into their lives, which all refuted. I lashed out, said horrible things and stopped trying to be in their lives. My mom will stop by on my birthday for 10 minutes or so and drop a card off at Christmas. As for my two older brothers and my father, it‚Äôs radio silence. I guess what I‚Äôm asking is, what do I do to fix this and fast, as I said I‚Äôve turned 40 this year, my parents are both 70. Time is running out, and I couldn‚Äôt imagine living my life without some kind of acceptance from my father. Or knowing he did or does love me. My heart breaks at the thought, but this is a real pickle. How can I fix a problem when the ones I need to fix it with won‚Äôt talk to me? Representative_Docs: ['AI song generator Udio offers brief window for downloads after Universal settlement upsets users Artificial intelligence song generation platform Udio said it would give its frustrated users 48 hours starting Monday to download their songs before the company shifts to a new business model to comply with a legal settlement. The short reprieve comes after Udio on Wednesday said it had settled copyright infringement claims brought by Universal Music, a label with artists including Taylor Swift, Olivia Rodrigo, Drake and Kendrick Lamar. AI companies are now fighting so many copyright lawsuits that a tech industry lobby group, the Chamber of Progress, last week called on President Donald Trump to sign an executive order directing federal attorneys "to intervene in legal cases" to defend the industry\'s practice of building generative AI tools by feeding them on copyrighted works. Citing more than 50 pending federal cases, the group asked for help stopping court fights leading to "potentially company-killing penalties" that threaten AI innovation.
